title: Lutheran Schools
description:
Lutheran schools are Christian educational institutions affiliated with Lutheran church bodies. These schools follow the Protestant tradition established during the Reformation, emphasizing grace, faith, and Scripture.

Key characteristics of Lutheran schools:

• Education rooted in Martin Luther's theology of grace through faith
• Strong emphasis on Scripture as the foundation of teaching
• Catechism instruction and Lutheran doctrinal education
• Integration of faith across all subject areas
• Often feature traditional liturgical worship
• Strong academic traditions dating back centuries

Lutheran schools in the United States may be affiliated with different Lutheran church bodies, including the Lutheran Church-Missouri Synod (LCMS), Evangelical Lutheran Church in America (ELCA), or Wisconsin Evangelical Lutheran Synod (WELS). Each has somewhat different theological emphases.

Lutheran schools have a long history of academic excellence, with many offering rigorous classical education approaches alongside faith formation.

When considering a Lutheran school, ask about their specific Lutheran synod affiliation, confirmation requirements, and how Lutheran theology is taught to students of various backgrounds.
